So why does quantum fluctuations violate special relativity?

If an observer O measures a dust cloud in space, they get a height h, width w, depth d, and a number N of particles. They calculate the density D = N / hwd.

Another observer O' moving at velocity v relative to O has a time dilation of ɣ = 1/√(1-v²/c²). They measure the dust cloud and get h', w', d', and N' where: h' = h, w' =w, d' = d/ɣ, and N'=N. Their density D' = N' / h'w'd' = N / hw(d/ɣ) = ɣ N / hwd = ɣD. The density increases for a moving observer.

So why doesn't the quantum fluctuations density also increase for a moving observer? And if it did so, then there must be a preferred frame of reference.

It's not mathematically formulated and in fact boils down to using analagous comparisons to explain why the path of photons can't be reliably predicted when performing the double slit experiment.

Basically the hypothesis says space is not empy but a massless slowmoving fluid and particles create waves in that fluid like matter in water. The fluid is slow in rebounding, so when particles follow from the same source the interference of the previous particle is still existing allowing for the behavior of particles to behave like waves and particles at the same time.

Quantum science has always stumped me. I'm no expert, but I want to understand what is going on.

Our senses, and the tools/machines that 'sense', if you will, what we can't can't normally sense, sense extremely small entities as a wave, but the bigger particles are 'sensed' as matter. OK, you can argue that if somebody threw a colony of bacteria at you from behind, you wouldn't sense it, despite there being millions of molecules in that colony, but there'd be a machine of some type that could. Empty space I now imagine as being composed of small entities, so small in fact, that electrons and protons do not interact with them, normally. They just sail through them. "Empty space is Not empty" -- Well then it's not really empty space, is it? It's just what we THOUGHT was empty space.

Similarly, If I'm looking into a dark room that I believe is empty, but it turns out there are several individuals hiding in the room in such a way that they are not visible to me at the moment, that means the room is not empty regardless of what I think. So if I called it an empty room, I would just be incorrect. With that in mind, I'd propose that it's time for us to stop calling empty space "empty space" and just call it space. By that same token, it's probably time for us to stop calling nothing "nothing" if it turns out its actually "something" since quite obviously, no thing or grouping of things (no matter the size) can be both nothing and something simultaneously.

A quick lesson in logic will go a long way in revealing the dangers of manipulating language to create new meanings. It's important to remember that language is a construct and as such it reflects our UNDERSTANDING and not necessarily the REALITY of the world we live in.

The greater and more accurate our measurement, the more there is to be measured.   It is the grid itself that is in a state of flux - its contents show when we perceive it as fixed.  We effectively give rise to objects out of nothing when we affix a grid upon it.

It's like looking for the missing mass - the more we look, the more we miss!

Try to capture a circle using squares.  Those squares must then permanently recede in scale towards a singular point and increase in quantity in order to accurately do so.  At any point that we choose a size of square to measure our circle with, we must add or take away from that circle.  A circle cannot be perceived without reconciling its edge.  (just as we might truncate pi to an approximation).  Likewise it can have more than one circumference at any one point.  It can be said to be rippling in waveform, or composed of a string of pearls.  (or, in fractal, both).  It also cannot be in a fixed state.  A circle in stasis being an irrational concept. The observer truly interferes and a state of vacuum cannot exist as we know it, literally, within our sphere of observable influence.  To 'observe it' is to give it form, to 'give' mass.  'Wrung from the flux'.

More so it is about the non-zero probability that ascribes an 'existential certainty' about when a vacuum might exist, (at every perceivable moment, and ~simultaneously~never - but for a length of time that can (and cannot) be classed as a single instant, but still above zero!  Never 'where'.  This also reduces our entire measurable universe into one unit, which is then surrounded by vacuum, which itself cannot exist because 'there is a universe in it'.  OR, strung like pearls as part of a multiverse which is itself conforming to a singular greater Universe which turns out to be part of a multi, which conforms to a singlular... ad infinitum ad nauseum.  Doubt we can ever know that one.

To put boundaries on it is to prevent its (non!)existence.  Concept of vacuum and universe go and hand in hand and are equally vague and quite irrational.  We might say that inflation is not caused from positive pressure within, but by negative pressure without....

If a vacuum is to exist within a certain timespan, we must remove ourselves from the universe - observing a universe removed from us - as unit flashing in and out of existence at a rate that is immeasurable to any fixable scale.  But does such universe 'carry on where it left off''  Or does it play itself out once for every infinitesimal?  And for every single reason or purpose, could it be possibly said to have ever flashed at all?

(Is there a theoretical moment when there is nothing coming or going?  Throw a ball in the air, straight up, and for how long exactly was it stationary before it changed direction?  Answer, daresay, is: How long does it take a universe to play out?

To speak it that way, I'd ask whether the universe is borrowing energy, but paying it back so quickly it was never borrowed in the first place.... (as far as any observer may as well be concerned)  Or, is it borrowing it (constantly?) at a definable rate, and paying it back so slowly that it can never pay it all back... (as far as any observer may as well be concerned)?

In fact so fast (and unbroken/smoothly) must it exist (and likewise not exist) that it could only be perceived as actual in any sense if the observer is in total consonance.  But this cannot be so, because we (our universe) exists.  Slight perturbations in symmetry have thrown particles into existence, it seems.  If we are all subject to vibrations which we can never possibly perceive without removing ourselves from this theoretical consonance, it gets a bit stringy.  Needless to suggesst - to do this would be to place ourselves 'outside the universe', by any current definition - which means not just some sort of 'superluminal escape velocity' but peering so deep into the transactions underneath that we begin to dissolve the fabric.

However, if you are asking what happens to helium as it rises in Earth's atmosphere, then they don't really escape into space.  They just float up to where they'd sit according to their density.  Air obeys gravity just like everything else.  We swim in air rather like fish swim in water.

Helium atoms, or really atoms in general, obey several laws.  Some would be attracted to you because of your rather small gravitational field.  Others would be repulsed because gasses like to expand to fill empty space. The bottom line is that space with the lowest amount of stuff in it is actually still full of stuff.
